header_1: H5N1 in Wild birds in USA

header_2: H5N1 in Wild birds in Germany
content_2: Reuters reported on October 25 that bird flu may become endemic in parts of Europe. "It seems that a new chapter in the evolution of avian influenza may be unfolding silently in the heart of Europe," Joseph Domenech, chief veterinary officer of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), said in a statement. The statement came after German scientists detected H5N1 in dead domestic ducks which had appeared to be healthy. Domenech said that H5N1 may become endemic in parts of Europe, such as the Black Sea area, because domestic ducks and geese are more of a vector in the spread of bird flu than previously thought.
content_3: A study from Liverpool University predicts that if bird flu was found on a farm in the UK, the spread of the virus would be limited to the single farm 73% of the time. In addition, the researchers found that the spread would be limited to only a small number of other sites the rest of the time because of safeguards already in place.
content_4: Bird flu has been detected in Vietnam for a second time this month. Recently, 310 two-month old ducklings have died (290 of them died on October 23) at a farm in the central province of Quang Tri. H5N1 has been found in the dead ducks, according to the Hoang Van Nam, the head of the Agriculture Ministryâ€™s Animal Health Department. (more...)
